natural problem: A point $P$ is chosen at random in the interior of equilateral triangle $ABC$. What is the probability that $\triangle ABP$ has a greater area than each of $\triangle ACP$ and $\triangle BCP$?
natural solution: Since the three triangles $ABP$, $ACP$, and $BCP$ have equal bases, their areas are proportional to the lengths of their altitudes.

Let $O$ be the centroid of $\triangle ABC$, and draw medians $\overline{AOE}$ and $\overline{BOD}$. Any point above $\overline{BOD}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$ than from $\overline{BC},$ and any point above $\overline{AOE}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$  than from $\overline{AC}.$ Therefore the condition of the problem is met if and only if $P$ is inside quadrilateral $CDOE.$

[asy] pair A,B,C,D,I,F,O; A=(0,0); B=(10,0); C=(5,8.7); D=(2.5,4.3); I=(7.5,4.3); F=(5,0); O=(5,2.3); draw(A--B--C--cycle,linewidth(0.7)); draw(A--I,linewidth(0.7)); draw(B--D,linewidth(0.7)); draw(C--F,dashed);

label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,E); label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,NW); label("$E$",I,NE); label("$F$",F,S); label("$O$",O,SW); [/asy] If $\overline{CO}$ is extended to $F$ on $\overline{AB}$, then $\triangle ABC$ is divided into six congruent triangles, of which two comprise quadrilateral $CDOE$.
Thus $CDOE$ has one-third the area of $\triangle ABC,$ so the required probability is $\boxed{\frac{1}{3}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "point" and triangle_ABC :: "triangle" and triangle_ABP :: "triangle" and triangle_ACP :: "triangle" and triangle_BCP :: "triangle"
assumes h0 : "equilateral triangle_ABC"
and h1 : "P \<in> interior triangle_ABC"
and h2 : "triangle_ABP = triangle_from_points A B P"
and h3 : "triangle_ACP = triangle_from_points A C P"
and h4 : "triangle_BCP = triangle_from_points B C P"
shows  "probability (area triangle_ABP > area triangle_ACP \<and> area triangle_ABP > area triangle_BCP) = 1 / 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen at random in the interior of equilateral triangle $ABC$. What is the probability that $\triangle ABP$ has a greater area than each of $\triangle ACP$ and $\triangle BCP$? The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 Since the three triangles $ABP$, $ACP$, and $BCP$ have equal bases, their areas are proportional to the lengths of their altitudes.
 Let $O$ be the centroid of $\triangle ABC$, and draw medians $\overline{AOE}$ and $\overline{BOD}$. Any point above $\overline{BOD}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$ than from $\overline{BC},$ and any point above $\overline{AOE}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$  than from $\overline{AC}.$ Therefore the condition of the problem is met if and only if $P$ is inside quadrilateral $CDOE.$
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,I,F,O; A=(0,0); B=(10,0); C=(5,8.7); D=(2.5,4.3); I=(7.5,4.3); F=(5,0); O=(5,2.3); draw(A--B--C--cycle,linewidth(0.7)); draw(A--I,linewidth(0.7)); draw(B--D,linewidth(0.7)); draw(C--F,dashed);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,E); label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,NW); label("$E$",I,NE); label("$F$",F,S); label("$O$",O,SW); [/asy] If $\overline{CO}$ is extended to $F$ on $\overline{AB}$, then $\triangle ABC$ is divided into six congruent triangles, of which two comprise quadrilateral $CDOE$.
 Thus $CDOE$ has one-third the area of $\triangle ABC,$ so the required probability is $\boxed{\frac{1}{3}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "point" and triangle_ABC :: "triangle" and triangle_ABP :: "triangle" and triangle_ACP :: "triangle" and triangle_BCP :: "triangle"
assumes h0 : "equilateral triangle_ABC"
and h1 : "P \<in> interior triangle_ABC"
and h2 : "triangle_ABP = triangle_from_points A B P"
and h3 : "triangle_ACP = triangle_from_points A C P"
and h4 : "triangle_BCP = triangle_from_points B C P"
shows  "probability (area triangle_ABP > area triangle_ACP \<and> area triangle_ABP > area triangle_BCP) = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In an equilateral triangle ABC, point P lies in its interior. Consider three triangles formed by the vertices A, B, C, and point P: triangle ABP, triangle ACP, and triangle BCP. What is the probability that the area of triangle ABP is greater than both the areas of triangle ACP and triangle BCP? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P A B C :: "real * real"
and area_AB_ACP :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
and area_AB_BCP :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
and area_AB_ABC :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "area_AB_ABC A B C > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> P. area_AB_ACP A B P + area_AB_BCP A B P = area_AB_ABC A B C"
and h2 : "\<forall> P. area_AB_ACP A B P > 0 \<and> area_AB_BCP A B P > 0"
shows  "prob {P. area_AB_ACP A B P > area_AB_BCP A B P \<and> area_AB_ACP A B P > area_AB_ABC A B C / 3} = 1 / 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen at random in the interior of equilateral triangle $ABC$. What is the probability that $\triangle ABP$ has a greater area than each of $\triangle ACP$ and $\triangle BCP$? The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 Since the three triangles $ABP$, $ACP$, and $BCP$ have equal bases, their areas are proportional to the lengths of their altitudes.
 Let $O$ be the centroid of $\triangle ABC$, and draw medians $\overline{AOE}$ and $\overline{BOD}$. Any point above $\overline{BOD}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$ than from $\overline{BC},$ and any point above $\overline{AOE}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$  than from $\overline{AC}.$ Therefore the condition of the problem is met if and only if $P$ is inside quadrilateral $CDOE.$
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,I,F,O; A=(0,0); B=(10,0); C=(5,8.7); D=(2.5,4.3); I=(7.5,4.3); F=(5,0); O=(5,2.3); draw(A--B--C--cycle,linewidth(0.7)); draw(A--I,linewidth(0.7)); draw(B--D,linewidth(0.7)); draw(C--F,dashed);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,E); label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,NW); label("$E$",I,NE); label("$F$",F,S); label("$O$",O,SW); [/asy] If $\overline{CO}$ is extended to $F$ on $\overline{AB}$, then $\triangle ABC$ is divided into six congruent triangles, of which two comprise quadrilateral $CDOE$.
 Thus $CDOE$ has one-third the area of $\triangle ABC,$ so the required probability is $\boxed{\frac{1}{3}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P A B C :: "real * real"
and area_AB_ACP :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
and area_AB_BCP :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
and area_AB_ABC :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "area_AB_ABC A B C > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> P. area_AB_ACP A B P + area_AB_BCP A B P = area_AB_ABC A B C"
and h2 : "\<forall> P. area_AB_ACP A B P > 0 \<and> area_AB_BCP A B P > 0"
shows  "prob {P. area_AB_ACP A B P > area_AB_BCP A B P \<and> area_AB_ACP A B P > area_AB_ABC A B C / 3} = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a triangle $ABC$ with a positive area, let $area_{AB,ACP}(A, B, P)$ denote the area of triangle $ACP$ with vertices $A$, $B$, and $P$, and similarly let $area_{AB,BCP}(A, B, P)$ denote the area of triangle $BCP$. It is known that for any point $P$, the sum of the areas of triangles $ACP$ and $BCP$ is equal to the area of triangle $ABC$. Also, the areas of both triangles $ACP$ and $BCP$ are always positive. What is the probability that, for a randomly chosen point $P$, the area of triangle $ACP$ is greater than the area of triangle $BCP$ and greater than one-third of the area of triangle $ABC$? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real * real" and A B C :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "equilateral_triangle A B C"
and h1 : "P \<in> interior A B C"
shows  "prob {\<triangle> A B P has_greater_area \<triangle> A C P, \<triangle> B C P} = 1 / 3"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen at random in the interior of equilateral triangle $ABC$. What is the probability that $\triangle ABP$ has a greater area than each of $\triangle ACP$ and $\triangle BCP$? The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 Since the three triangles $ABP$, $ACP$, and $BCP$ have equal bases, their areas are proportional to the lengths of their altitudes.
 Let $O$ be the centroid of $\triangle ABC$, and draw medians $\overline{AOE}$ and $\overline{BOD}$. Any point above $\overline{BOD}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$ than from $\overline{BC},$ and any point above $\overline{AOE}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$  than from $\overline{AC}.$ Therefore the condition of the problem is met if and only if $P$ is inside quadrilateral $CDOE.$
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,I,F,O; A=(0,0); B=(10,0); C=(5,8.7); D=(2.5,4.3); I=(7.5,4.3); F=(5,0); O=(5,2.3); draw(A--B--C--cycle,linewidth(0.7)); draw(A--I,linewidth(0.7)); draw(B--D,linewidth(0.7)); draw(C--F,dashed);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,E); label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,NW); label("$E$",I,NE); label("$F$",F,S); label("$O$",O,SW); [/asy] If $\overline{CO}$ is extended to $F$ on $\overline{AB}$, then $\triangle ABC$ is divided into six congruent triangles, of which two comprise quadrilateral $CDOE$.
 Thus $CDOE$ has one-third the area of $\triangle ABC,$ so the required probability is $\boxed{\frac{1}{3}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real * real" and A B C :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "equilateral_triangle A B C"
and h1 : "P \<in> interior A B C"
shows  "prob {\<triangle> A B P has_greater_area \<triangle> A C P, \<triangle> B C P} = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In an equilateral triangle ABC, if point P lies in the interior of the triangle, what is the probability that the area of triangle ABP is greater than the areas of triangles ACP and BCP? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "equilateral_triangle A B C"
and h1 : "interior_point P A B C"
shows  "probability (area_triangle A B P > area_triangle A C P \<and> area_triangle A B P > area_triangle B C P) = 1/3"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen at random in the interior of equilateral triangle $ABC$. What is the probability that $\triangle ABP$ has a greater area than each of $\triangle ACP$ and $\triangle BCP$? The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 Since the three triangles $ABP$, $ACP$, and $BCP$ have equal bases, their areas are proportional to the lengths of their altitudes.
 Let $O$ be the centroid of $\triangle ABC$, and draw medians $\overline{AOE}$ and $\overline{BOD}$. Any point above $\overline{BOD}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$ than from $\overline{BC},$ and any point above $\overline{AOE}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$  than from $\overline{AC}.$ Therefore the condition of the problem is met if and only if $P$ is inside quadrilateral $CDOE.$
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,I,F,O; A=(0,0); B=(10,0); C=(5,8.7); D=(2.5,4.3); I=(7.5,4.3); F=(5,0); O=(5,2.3); draw(A--B--C--cycle,linewidth(0.7)); draw(A--I,linewidth(0.7)); draw(B--D,linewidth(0.7)); draw(C--F,dashed);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,E); label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,NW); label("$E$",I,NE); label("$F$",F,S); label("$O$",O,SW); [/asy] If $\overline{CO}$ is extended to $F$ on $\overline{AB}$, then $\triangle ABC$ is divided into six congruent triangles, of which two comprise quadrilateral $CDOE$.
 Thus $CDOE$ has one-third the area of $\triangle ABC,$ so the required probability is $\boxed{\frac{1}{3}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "equilateral_triangle A B C"
and h1 : "interior_point P A B C"
shows  "probability (area_triangle A B P > area_triangle A C P \<and> area_triangle A B P > area_triangle B C P) = 1/3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In an equilateral triangle $ABC$, let $P$ be a point inside the triangle. What is the probability that the area of triangle $ABP$ is greater than both the areas of triangles $ACP$ and $BCP$? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "P \<in> interior (equilateral_triangle ABC)"
and h1 : "area (triangle ABP) > area (triangle ACP)"
and h2 : "area (triangle ABP) > area (triangle BCP)"
shows  "prob {P \<in> interior (equilateral_triangle ABC). area (triangle ABP) > area (triangle ACP) \<and> area (triangle ABP) > area (triangle BCP)} = 1 / 3"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen at random in the interior of equilateral triangle $ABC$. What is the probability that $\triangle ABP$ has a greater area than each of $\triangle ACP$ and $\triangle BCP$? The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 Since the three triangles $ABP$, $ACP$, and $BCP$ have equal bases, their areas are proportional to the lengths of their altitudes.
 Let $O$ be the centroid of $\triangle ABC$, and draw medians $\overline{AOE}$ and $\overline{BOD}$. Any point above $\overline{BOD}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$ than from $\overline{BC},$ and any point above $\overline{AOE}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$  than from $\overline{AC}.$ Therefore the condition of the problem is met if and only if $P$ is inside quadrilateral $CDOE.$

 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,E); label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,NW); label("$E$",I,NE); label("$F$",F,S); label("$O$",O,SW); [/asy] If $\overline{CO}$ is extended to $F$ on $\overline{AB}$, then $\triangle ABC$ is divided into six congruent triangles, of which two comprise quadrilateral $CDOE$.

 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "P \<in> interior (equilateral_triangle ABC)"
and h1 : "area (triangle ABP) > area (triangle ACP)"
and h2 : "area (triangle ABP) > area (triangle BCP)"
shows  "prob {P \<in> interior (equilateral_triangle ABC). area (triangle ABP) > area (triangle ACP) \<and> area (triangle ABP) > area (triangle BCP)} = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In an equilateral triangle $ABC$, a point $P$ is chosen in the interior such that the area of $\triangle ABP$ is greater than the area of both $\triangle ACP$ and $\triangle BCP$. What is the probability that a randomly chosen point $P$ inside the equilateral triangle $ABC$ satisfies these conditions? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real 2" and A B C :: "real 2"
assumes h0 : "is_equilateral A B C"
and h1 : "P \<in> interior (convex_hull {A, B, C})"
shows  "prob {(A, B, P) |area_triangle A B P > area_triangle A C P \<and> area_triangle A B P > area_triangle B C P} = 1 / 3"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen at random in the interior of equilateral triangle $ABC$. What is the probability that $\triangle ABP$ has a greater area than each of $\triangle ACP$ and $\triangle BCP$? The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 Since the three triangles $ABP$, $ACP$, and $BCP$ have equal bases, their areas are proportional to the lengths of their altitudes.
 Let $O$ be the centroid of $\triangle ABC$, and draw medians $\overline{AOE}$ and $\overline{BOD}$. Any point above $\overline{BOD}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$ than from $\overline{BC},$ and any point above $\overline{AOE}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$  than from $\overline{AC}.$ Therefore the condition of the problem is met if and only if $P$ is inside quadrilateral $CDOE.$
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,I,F,O; A=(0,0); B=(10,0); C=(5,8.7); D=(2.5,4.3); I=(7.5,4.3); F=(5,0); O=(5,2.3); draw(A--B--C--cycle,linewidth(0.7)); draw(A--I,linewidth(0.7)); draw(B--D,linewidth(0.7)); draw(C--F,dashed);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,E); label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,NW); label("$E$",I,NE); label("$F$",F,S); label("$O$",O,SW); [/asy] If $\overline{CO}$ is extended to $F$ on $\overline{AB}$, then $\triangle ABC$ is divided into six congruent triangles, of which two comprise quadrilateral $CDOE$.
 Thus $CDOE$ has one-third the area of $\triangle ABC,$ so the required probability is $\boxed{\frac{1}{3}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real 2" and A B C :: "real 2"
assumes h0 : "is_equilateral A B C"
and h1 : "P \<in> interior (convex_hull {A, B, C})"
shows  "prob {(A, B, P) |area_triangle A B P > area_triangle A C P \<and> area_triangle A B P > area_triangle B C P} = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In an equilateral triangle ABC, a point P lies inside the triangle. What is the probability that the area of triangle ABP is greater than both the areas of triangles ACP and BCP? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and area :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P \<in> interior (triangle ABC)"
and h1 : "area (triangle ABP) > area (triangle ACP)"
and h2 : "area (triangle ABP) > area (triangle BCP)"
shows  "probability P = 1 / 3"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen at random in the interior of equilateral triangle $ABC$. What is the probability that $\triangle ABP$ has a greater area than each of $\triangle ACP$ and $\triangle BCP$? The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof

 Let $O$ be the centroid of $\triangle ABC$, and draw medians $\overline{AOE}$ and $\overline{BOD}$. Any point above $\overline{BOD}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$ than from $\overline{BC},$ and any point above $\overline{AOE}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$  than from $\overline{AC}.$ Therefore the condition of the problem is met if and only if $P$ is inside quadrilateral $CDOE.$
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,I,F,O; A=(0,0); B=(10,0); C=(5,8.7); D=(2.5,4.3); I=(7.5,4.3); F=(5,0); O=(5,2.3); draw(A--B--C--cycle,linewidth(0.7)); draw(A--I,linewidth(0.7)); draw(B--D,linewidth(0.7)); draw(C--F,dashed);

 Thus $CDOE$ has one-third the area of $\triangle ABC,$ so the required probability is $\boxed{\frac{1}{3}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and area :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P \<in> interior (triangle ABC)"
and h1 : "area (triangle ABP) > area (triangle ACP)"
and h2 : "area (triangle ABP) > area (triangle BCP)"
shows  "probability P = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a triangle ABC, point P is in the interior of the triangle. The area of triangle ABP is greater than the area of triangle ACP, and the area of triangle ABP is greater than the area of triangle BCP. Find the probability of P occurring. The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real*real" and A B C :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "equilateral_triangle A B C"
and h1 : "P \<in> interior A B C"
shows  "probability (area_triangle A B P > area_triangle A C P \<and> area_triangle A B P > area_triangle B C P) = 1/3"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen at random in the interior of equilateral triangle $ABC$. What is the probability that $\triangle ABP$ has a greater area than each of $\triangle ACP$ and $\triangle BCP$? The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}

fixes P :: "real*real" and A B C :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "equilateral_triangle A B C"
and h1 : "P \<in> interior A B C"
shows  "probability (area_triangle A B P > area_triangle A C P \<and> area_triangle A B P > area_triangle B C P) = 1/3"

a_7.informal problem: In an equilateral triangle ABC, if point P is inside the triangle, what is the probability that the area of triangle ABP is greater than the areas of triangles ACP and BCP? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P A B C :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "P \<in> interior (triangle A B C)"
and h1 : "is_equilateral A B C"
shows  "area_triangle A B P > area_triangle A C P \<and> area_triangle A B P > area_triangle B C P \<longleftrightarrow> P_prob A B C = 1 / 3"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen at random in the interior of equilateral triangle $ABC$. What is the probability that $\triangle ABP$ has a greater area than each of $\triangle ACP$ and $\triangle BCP$? The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 Since the three triangles $ABP$, $ACP$, and $BCP$ have equal bases, their areas are proportional to the lengths of their altitudes.
 Let $O$ be the centroid of $\triangle ABC$, and draw medians $\overline{AOE}$ and $\overline{BOD}$. Any point above $\overline{BOD}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$ than from $\overline{BC},$ and any point above $\overline{AOE}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$  than from $\overline{AC}.$ Therefore the condition of the problem is met if and only if $P$ is inside quadrilateral $CDOE.$
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,I,F,O; A=(0,0); B=(10,0); C=(5,8.7); D=(2.5,4.3); I=(7.5,4.3); F=(5,0); O=(5,2.3); draw(A--B--C--cycle,linewidth(0.7)); draw(A--I,linewidth(0.7)); draw(B--D,linewidth(0.7)); draw(C--F,dashed);

 Thus $CDOE$ has one-third the area of $\triangle ABC,$ so the required probability is $\boxed{\frac{1}{3}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P A B C :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "P \<in> interior (triangle A B C)"
and h1 : "is_equilateral A B C"
shows  "area_triangle A B P > area_triangle A C P \<and> area_triangle A B P > area_triangle B C P \<longleftrightarrow> P_prob A B C = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In an equilateral triangle $ABC$, let $P$ be a point in the interior of the triangle. If the area of triangle $ABP$ is greater than the areas of triangles $ACP$ and $BCP$, what is the probability that this condition holds? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real^2" and ABC :: "real^2 set"
assumes h0 : "equilateral_triangle ABC"
and h1 : "P \<in> interior ABC"
shows  "P_measure {P \<in> interior ABC. triangle_area A B P > triangle_area A C P \<and> triangle_area A B P > triangle_area B C P} = 1 / 3"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A point $P$ is chosen at random in the interior of equilateral triangle $ABC$. What is the probability that $\triangle ABP$ has a greater area than each of $\triangle ACP$ and $\triangle BCP$? The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 Since the three triangles $ABP$, $ACP$, and $BCP$ have equal bases, their areas are proportional to the lengths of their altitudes.
 Let $O$ be the centroid of $\triangle ABC$, and draw medians $\overline{AOE}$ and $\overline{BOD}$. Any point above $\overline{BOD}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$ than from $\overline{BC},$ and any point above $\overline{AOE}$ will be farther from $\overline{AB}$  than from $\overline{AC}.$ Therefore the condition of the problem is met if and only if $P$ is inside quadrilateral $CDOE.$
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,I,F,O; A=(0,0); B=(10,0); C=(5,8.7); D=(2.5,4.3); I=(7.5,4.3); F=(5,0); O=(5,2.3); draw(A--B--C--cycle,linewidth(0.7)); draw(A--I,linewidth(0.7)); draw(B--D,linewidth(0.7)); draw(C--F,dashed);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,E); label("$C$",C,N); label("$D$",D,NW); label("$E$",I,NE); label("$F$",F,S); label("$O$",O,SW); [/asy] If $\overline{CO}$ is extended to $F$ on $\overline{AB}$, then $\triangle ABC$ is divided into six congruent triangles, of which two comprise quadrilateral $CDOE$.
 Thus $CDOE$ has one-third the area of $\triangle ABC,$ so the required probability is $\boxed{\frac{1}{3}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real^2" and ABC :: "real^2 set"
assumes h0 : "equilateral_triangle ABC"
and h1 : "P \<in> interior ABC"
shows  "P_measure {P \<in> interior ABC. triangle_area A B P > triangle_area A C P \<and> triangle_area A B P > triangle_area B C P} = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In an equilateral triangle ABC, let P be a point in its interior. What is the probability that the area of triangle ABP is greater than the area of triangle ACP and the area of triangle ABP is greater than the area of triangle BCP? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.
